# Immigration to the United States

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/L-15-12-22-A-036_%2823914007905%29.jpg/300px-L-15-12-22-A-036_%2823914007905%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:L-15-12-22-A-036_\(23914007905\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:L-15-12-22-A-036_\(23914007905\).jpg "Enlarge")

Naturalization ceremony at the [Oakton High School](/wiki/Oakton_High_School
"Oakton High School") in Virginia, December 2015.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Naturalization_Ceremony_Grand_Canyon_20100923mq_0555_%285021872334%29.jpg/300px-
Naturalization_Ceremony_Grand_Canyon_20100923mq_0555_%285021872334%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Naturalization_Ceremony_Grand_Canyon_20100923mq_0555_\(5021872334\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Naturalization_Ceremony_Grand_Canyon_20100923mq_0555_\(5021872334\).jpg
"Enlarge")

Immigrants to the United States take the [Oath of
Allegiance](/wiki/Oath_of_Allegiance_\(United_States\) "Oath of Allegiance
\(United States\)") at a naturalization ceremony at the [Grand Canyon National
Park](/wiki/Grand_Canyon_National_Park "Grand Canyon National Park") in
[Arizona](/wiki/Arizona "Arizona"), September 2010.

**Immigration to the United States** is the international movement of
individuals who are not natives or do not possess
[citizenship](/wiki/Citizenship "Citizenship") in order to settle, reside,
study, or work in the country. It has been a major source of [population
growth](/wiki/Population_growth "Population growth") and cultural change
throughout much of the [history of the United
States](/wiki/History_of_the_United_States "History of the United States").
Because the United States is a [settler colonial
society](/wiki/Settler_colonialism "Settler colonialism"), the vast majority
of Americans, with the exception of [Native
Americans](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States "Native Americans in
the United States"), can trace their ancestry to immigrants from other
nations.

In absolute numbers, the United States has a larger immigrant population than
any other country, with 47 million immigrants as of 2015.[1] This represents
19.1% of the 244 million international migrants worldwide, and 14.4% of the
U.S. population. Many other countries have large proportions of immigrants,
such as [Switzerland with 24.9%](/wiki/Immigration_to_Switzerland "Immigration
to Switzerland") and [Canada with 21.9%](/wiki/Immigration_to_Canada
"Immigration to Canada").[2][3]

According to the 2016 Yearbook of Immigration Statistics, the United States
admitted 1.18 million legal immigrants in 2016.[4] Of these, 20% were family-
sponsored, 47% were the immediate relatives of U.S. citizens, 12% were
employment-based preferences, 4% were part of the [Diversity Immigrant
Visa](/wiki/Diversity_Immigrant_Visa "Diversity Immigrant Visa") program, and
13% were refugees and asylum-seekers.[4] The remainder included small numbers
from several other categories, including interpreters and other Iraqis and
Afghans employed by U.S. Government; persons admitted under the [Nicaraguan
and Central American Relief
Act](/wiki/Nicaraguan_and_Central_American_Relief_Act "Nicaraguan and Central
American Relief Act"); children born subsequent to the issuance of a parent's
visa; and certain parolees from the former Soviet Union, Cambodia, Laos, or
Vietnam who were denied refugee status.[4]

The economic, social, and political aspects of immigration have caused
controversy regarding such issues as mainitaining [ethnic
homogeneity](/wiki/American_ethnicity "American ethnicity"), workers for
employers versus jobs for non-immigrants, settlement patterns, impact on
upward [social mobility](/wiki/Socioeconomic_mobility_in_the_United_States
"Socioeconomic mobility in the United States"),
[crime](/wiki/Crime_in_the_United_States "Crime in the United States"), and
voting behavior.

Prior to 1965, policies such as the [national origins
formula](/wiki/National_Origins_Formula "National Origins Formula") limited
[immigration](/wiki/Immigration "Immigration") and
[naturalization](/wiki/Naturalization "Naturalization") opportunities for
people from areas outside [Western Europe](/wiki/Western_Europe "Western
Europe"). Exclusion laws enacted as early as the 1880s generally prohibited or
severely restricted immigration from Asia, and quota laws enacted in the 1920s
curtailed Eastern European immigration. The [civil rights
movement](/wiki/Civil_rights_movement "Civil rights movement") led to the
[replacement](/wiki/Immigration_and_Nationality_Act_of_1965 "Immigration and
Nationality Act of 1965")[5] of these ethnic quotas with per-country
limits.[6] Since then, the number of first-generation immigrants living in the
United States has quadrupled.[7][8]

Research suggests that immigration to the United States is beneficial to the
US economy. With few exceptions, the evidence suggests that on average,
immigration has positive economic effects on the native population, but it is
mixed as to whether low-skilled immigration adversely affects low-skilled
natives. Studies also show that immigrants have lower crime rates than natives
in the United States.[9][10][11] Research shows that the United States excels
at assimilating first- and second-generation immigrants relative to many other
Western countries.

## History

Main article: [History of immigration to the United
States](/wiki/History_of_immigration_to_the_United_States "History of
immigration to the United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Welcome_to_the_land_of_freedom.png/250px-
Welcome_to_the_land_of_freedom.png)](/wiki/File:Welcome_to_the_land_of_freedom.png)

[](/wiki/File:Welcome_to_the_land_of_freedom.png "Enlarge")

Immigrants on ocean steamer passing the Statue of Liberty, New York City, 1887

American immigration history can be viewed in four epochs: the colonial
period, the mid-19th century, the start of the 20th century, and post-1965.
Each period brought distinct national groups, races and ethnicities to the
United States. During the 17th century, approximately 400,000 English people
migrated to Colonial America.[12] However only half stayed permanently. From
1700 to 1775 between 400-500,000 immigrated. Only 45,000 English supposedly
immigrated in the period 1701 to 1775 (on Butler, Becoming America, The
Revolution before 1776, 2000, p. 34-35
[ISBN](/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number "International Standard Book
Number") [0-674-00091-9](/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-674-00091-9
"Special:BookSources/0-674-00091-9")), a figure questioned as too low (The
Oxford History of the British Empire, The Eighteenth Century, Ed. P. J.
Marshall, p. 3 [ISBN](/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number "International
Standard Book Number") [0-19-820563-5](/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-19-820563-5
"Special:BookSources/0-19-820563-5") the number given is at 80,000 less 29,000
Welsh which seems strange to the author, James Horn; Duncan also regards this
as a "mystery") not including the 50,000-120,000 convicts transported, most of
whom were English: the rest, 400-450,000 were Scots, Scots-Irish from Ulster,
Germans and Swiss, French Huguenots, and involuntarily 350,000 Africans
(Encyclopedia of the Colonial and Revolutionary America, 1996 p. 200-202
[ISBN](/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number "International Standard Book
Number") [0-306-80687-8](/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-306-80687-8
"Special:BookSources/0-306-80687-8"); Jon Butler, Becoming America, The
Revolution before 1776, 2000, pp. 16–49
[ISBN](/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number "International Standard Book
Number") [0-674-00091-9](/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-674-00091-9
"Special:BookSources/0-674-00091-9")). Over half of all European immigrants to
Colonial America during the 17th and 18th centuries arrived as [indentured
servants](/wiki/Indentured_servant "Indentured servant").[13] They numbered
350,000 (Encyclopedia, p. 202). The European populations of the Middle
Colonies of New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware were ethnically
very mixed, the English constituting only 30 in Pennsylvania, 40% in New
Jersey to 45% in New York (numbered22 thousand or 18% in NY) (Duncan. op. cit.
p. 10). The mid-19th century saw an influx mainly from northern Europe from
the same major ethnic groups as for the Colonial Period but with large numbers
of Catholic Irish and Scandinavians added to the mix; the late 19th and early
20th-century immigrants were mainly from Southern and Eastern Europe, but
there were also several million immigrants from Canada; post-1965 most came
from Latin America and Asia.

Historians estimate that fewer than 1 million immigrants moved to the United
States from Europe between 1600 and 1799.[14] By comparison, in the first
federal census, in 1790, the population of the United States was enumerated to
be 3,929,214.[15] The [1790 Act](/wiki/Naturalization_Act_of_1790
"Naturalization Act of 1790") limited naturalization to "free white persons";
it was expanded to include blacks in the 1860s and Asians in the 1950s.[16] In
the early years of the United States, immigration was fewer than 8,000 people
a year,[17] including French refugees from the slave revolt in Haiti. After
1820, immigration gradually increased. From 1836 to 1914, over 30 million
Europeans migrated to the United States.[18] The death rate on these
transatlantic voyages was high, during which one in seven travelers died.[19]
In 1875, the nation passed its first immigration law, the [Page Act of
1875](/wiki/Page_Act_of_1875 "Page Act of 1875").[20]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Ellis_island_1902.jpg/250px-
Ellis_island_1902.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ellis_island_1902.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ellis_island_1902.jpg "Enlarge")

Immigrants arriving at [Ellis Island](/wiki/Ellis_Island "Ellis Island"), 1902

After an initial wave of immigration from China following the [California Gold
Rush](/wiki/California_Gold_Rush "California Gold Rush"), Congress passed a
series of laws culminating in the [Chinese Exclusion
Act](/wiki/Chinese_Exclusion_Act "Chinese Exclusion Act") of 1882, banning
virtually all immigration from China until the law's repeal in 1943. In the
late 1800s, [immigration from other Asian
countries](/wiki/Asian_immigration_to_the_United_States#First_major_wave_of_Asian_immigration_\(1850s-1917\)
"Asian immigration to the United States"), especially to the West Coast,
became more common.

The peak year of European immigration was in 1907, when 1,285,349 persons
entered the country.[21] By 1910, 13.5 million immigrants were living in the
United States.[22] In 1921, the Congress passed the [Emergency Quota
Act](/wiki/Emergency_Quota_Act "Emergency Quota Act"), followed by the
[Immigration Act of 1924](/wiki/Immigration_Act_of_1924 "Immigration Act of
1924"). The 1924 Act was aimed at further restricting immigrants from Southern
and Eastern Europe, particularly Jews, Italians, and Slavs, who had begun to
enter the country in large numbers beginning in the 1890s, and consolidated
the prohibition of [Asian
immigration](/wiki/Asian_immigration_to_the_United_States "Asian immigration
to the United States").[23]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Polish_berry_pickers_color.jpg/250px-
Polish_berry_pickers_color.jpg)](/wiki/File:Polish_berry_pickers_color.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Polish_berry_pickers_color.jpg "Enlarge")

Polish immigrants working on the farm, 1909. The
[welfare](/wiki/Social_programs_in_the_United_States "Social programs in the
United States") system was practically non-existent before the 1930s and the
economic pressures on the poor were giving rise to child labor.

Immigration patterns of the 1930s were affected by the [Great
Depression](/wiki/Great_Depression "Great Depression"). In the final
prosperous year, 1929, there were 279,678 immigrants recorded,[24] but in
1933, only 23,068 moved to the U.S.[14] In the early 1930s, more people
emigrated from the United States than to it.[25] The U.S. government sponsored
a [Mexican Repatriation](/wiki/Mexican_Repatriation "Mexican Repatriation")
program which was intended to encourage people to voluntarily move to Mexico,
but thousands were deported against their will.[26] Altogether about 400,000
Mexicans were repatriated half of them US citizens.[27] Most of the Jewish
refugees fleeing the Nazis and World War II were barred from coming to the
United States.[28] In the post-war era, the Justice Department launched
[Operation Wetback](/wiki/Operation_Wetback "Operation Wetback"), under which
1,075,168 Mexicans were deported in 1954.[29]

> First, our cities will not be flooded with a million immigrants annually.
> Under the proposed bill, the present level of immigration remains
> substantially the same. ... Secondly, the ethnic mix of this country will
> not be upset. ... Contrary to the charges in some quarters, [the bill] will
> not inundate America with immigrants from any one country or area, or the
> most populated and deprived nations of Africa and Asia. ... In the final
> analysis, the ethnic pattern of immigration under the proposed measure is
> not expected to change as sharply as the critics seem to think.
>
> — [Ted Kennedy](/wiki/Ted_Kennedy "Ted Kennedy"), chief Senate sponsor of
> the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1965.[30]

The [Immigration and Nationality Act of
1965](/wiki/Immigration_and_Nationality_Act_of_1965 "Immigration and
Nationality Act of 1965"), also known as the Hart-Cellar Act, abolished the
system of national-origin quotas. By equalizing immigration policies, the act
resulted in new immigration from non-European nations, which changed [the
ethnic make-up of the United States](/wiki/Demographics_of_the_United_States
"Demographics of the United States").[31] In 1970, 60% of immigrants were from
Europe; this decreased to 15% by 2000.[32] In 1990, [George H. W.
Bush](/wiki/George_H._W._Bush "George H. W. Bush") signed the [Immigration Act
of 1990](/wiki/Immigration_Act_of_1990 "Immigration Act of 1990"),[33] which
increased legal immigration to the United States by 40%.[34] In 1991, Bush
signed the [Armed Forces Immigration Adjustment Act
1991](/wiki/1991_Armed_Forces_Immigration_Adjustment_Act "1991 Armed Forces
Immigration Adjustment Act"), allowing foreign service members who had serve
12 or more years in the US Armed Forces to qualify for permanent residency
and, in some cases, citizenship.

In November 1994, California voters passed [Proposition
187](/wiki/Proposition_187 "Proposition 187") amending the state constitution,
denying state financial aid to illegal immigrants. The federal courts voided
this change, ruling that it violated the federal constitution.[35]

Appointed by Bill Clinton,[36] the [U.S. Commission on Immigration
Reform](/wiki/History_of_laws_concerning_immigration_and_naturalization_in_the_United_States#1990s
"History of laws concerning immigration and naturalization in the United
States") recommended reducing legal immigration from about 800,000 people per
year to approximately 550,000.[37] While an influx of new residents from
different cultures presents some challenges, "the United States has always
been energized by its immigrant populations," said President [Bill
Clinton](/wiki/Bill_Clinton "Bill Clinton") in 1998. "America has constantly
drawn strength and spirit from wave after wave of immigrants [...] They have
proved to be the most restless, the most adventurous, the most innovative, the
most industrious of people."[38]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Paifang_Boston_Chinatown_1.jpg/250px-
Paifang_Boston_Chinatown_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Paifang_Boston_Chinatown_1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Paifang_Boston_Chinatown_1.jpg "Enlarge")

[Boston Chinatown](/wiki/Boston_Chinatown "Boston Chinatown"), Massachusetts,
2008.

In 2001, President [George W. Bush](/wiki/George_W._Bush "George W. Bush")
discussed an accord with Mexican President [Vincente Fox](/wiki/Vincente_Fox
"Vincente Fox"). Possible accord was derailed by the [September 11
attacks](/wiki/September_11_attacks "September 11 attacks"). From 2005 to
2013, the US Congress discussed various ways of controlling immigration. The
Senate and House were unable to reach an agreement.[35]

Nearly 14 million immigrants entered the United States from 2000 to 2010,[39]
and over one million persons were [naturalized](/wiki/Naturalization
"Naturalization") as U.S. citizens in 2008. The per-country limit[6] applies
the same maximum on the number of visas to all countries regardless of their
population and has therefore had the effect of significantly restricting
immigration of persons born in populous nations such as Mexico, China, India,
and the Philippines—the leading countries of origin for legally admitted
immigrants to the United States in 2013;[40] nevertheless, China, India, and
Mexico were the leading countries of origin for immigrants overall to the
United States in 2013, regardless of legal status, according to a [U.S. Census
Bureau](/wiki/U.S._Census_Bureau "U.S. Census Bureau") study.[41] As of
2009[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Immigration_to_the_United_States&action=edit),
66% of legal immigrants were admitted on the basis of family ties, along with
13% admitted for their employment skills and 17% for humanitarian reasons.[42]

Nearly 8 million people immigrated to the United States from 2000 to 2005; 3.7
million of them entered without papers.[43][44] In 1986 president Ronald
Reagan signed immigration reform that gave amnesty to 3 million undocumented
immigrants in the country.[45] Hispanic immigrants suffered job losses during
the late-2000s recession,[46] but since the recession's end in June 2009,
immigrants posted a net gain of 656,000 jobs.[47] Over 1 million immigrants
were granted legal residence in 2011.[48]

For those who enter the US illegally across the [Mexico–United States
border](/wiki/Mexico%E2%80%93United_States_border "Mexico–United States
border") and elsewhere, migration is difficult, expensive and dangerous.[49]
Virtually all undocumented immigrants have no avenues for legal entry to the
United States due to the restrictive legal limits on [green
cards](/wiki/Permanent_residence_\(United_States\) "Permanent residence
\(United States\)"), and lack of immigrant [visas](/wiki/United_States_visa
"United States visa") for low-skilled workers.[50] Participants in debates on
immigration in the early twenty-first century called for increasing
enforcement of existing laws governing [illegal immigration to the United
States](/wiki/Illegal_immigration_to_the_United_States "Illegal immigration to
the United States"), building a
[barrier](/wiki/Mexico%E2%80%93United_States_barrier "Mexico–United States
barrier") along some or all of the 2,000-mile (3,200 km) Mexico-U.S. border,
or creating a new [guest worker](/wiki/Guest_worker "Guest worker") program.
Through much of 2006 the country and Congress was immersed in a debate about
these proposals. As of April
2010[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Immigration_to_the_United_States&action=edit)
few of these proposals had become law, though a partial border fence had been
approved and subsequently canceled.[51]

In January 2017, U.S. President [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald
Trump") signed an [executive order](/wiki/Executive_Order_13769 "Executive
Order 13769") temporarily suspending entry to the United States by nationals
of certain Muslim-majority countries. It was replaced by another [executive
order](/wiki/Executive_Order_13780 "Executive Order 13780") in March 2017 and
by a presidential proclamation in September 2017, with various changes to the
list of countries and exemptions.[52] The orders were temporarily suspended by
federal courts but later allowed to proceed by the Supreme Court, pending a
definite ruling on their legality.[53] Another executive order called for the
immediate construction of a [wall across the U.S.–Mexico
border](/wiki/Mexico%E2%80%93United_States_barrier "Mexico–United States
barrier"), the hiring of 5,000 new border patrol agents and 10,000 new
immigration officers, and federal funding penalties for [sanctuary
cities](/wiki/Sanctuary_city "Sanctuary city").[54]

## Contemporary immigration

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/SalemMassCustomHouseNaturalization3ty13543.jpg/220px-
SalemMassCustomHouseNaturalization3ty13543.jpg)](/wiki/File:SalemMassCustomHouseNaturalization3ty13543.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:SalemMassCustomHouseNaturalization3ty13543.jpg "Enlarge")

Naturalization ceremony, [Salem](/wiki/Salem,_Massachusetts "Salem,
Massachusetts"), Massachusetts, 2007

Until the 1930s most legal immigrants were male. By the 1990s women accounted
for just over half of all legal immigrants.[56] Contemporary immigrants tend
to be younger than the native population of the United States, with people
between the ages of 15 and 34 substantially overrepresented.[57] Immigrants
are also more likely to be married and less likely to be divorced than native-
born Americans of the same age.[58]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Iftar_in_Patterson_New_Jersey.jpg/210px-
Iftar_in_Patterson_New_Jersey.jpg)](/wiki/File:Iftar_in_Patterson_New_Jersey.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Iftar_in_Patterson_New_Jersey.jpg "Enlarge")

[Paterson, New Jersey](/wiki/Paterson,_New_Jersey "Paterson, New Jersey"),
within the [New York City Metropolitan
Area](/wiki/New_York_City_Metropolitan_Area "New York City Metropolitan
Area"), is becoming an increasingly popular destination for
[Muslim](/wiki/Islam_in_the_United_States "Islam in the United States")
immigrants.

Immigrants are likely to move to and live in areas populated by people with
similar backgrounds. This phenomenon has held true throughout the history of
immigration to the United States.[59] Seven out of ten immigrants surveyed by
[Public Agenda](/wiki/Public_Agenda "Public Agenda") in 2009 said they
intended to make the U.S. their permanent home, and 71% said if they could do
it over again they would still come to the US. In the same study, 76% of
immigrants say the government has become stricter on enforcing immigration
laws since the [September 11, 2001 attacks](/wiki/September_11,_2001_attacks
"September 11, 2001 attacks") ("9/11"), and 24% report that they personally
have experienced some or a great deal of discrimination.[60]

Public attitudes about immigration in the U.S. were heavily influenced in the
aftermath of the 9/11 attacks. After the attacks, 52% of Americans believed
that immigration was a good thing overall for the U.S., down from 62% the year
before, according to a 2009 Gallup poll.[61] A 2008 Public Agenda survey found
that half of Americans said tighter controls on immigration would do "a great
deal" to enhance U.S. national security.[62] Harvard political scientist and
historian [Samuel P. Huntington](/wiki/Samuel_P._Huntington "Samuel P.
Huntington") argued in his 2004 book _[Who Are We? The Challenges to America's
National
Identity](/wiki/Who_Are_We%3F_The_Challenges_to_America%27s_National_Identity
"Who Are We? The Challenges to America's National Identity")_ that a potential
future consequence of continuing massive immigration from Latin America,
especially Mexico, could lead to the bifurcation of the United States.[63][64]

The estimated population of illegal Mexican immigrants in the US fell from
approximately 7 million in 2007 to 6.1 million in 2011 [65] Commentators link
the reversal of the immigration trend to the economic downturn that started in
2008 and which meant fewer available jobs, and to the introduction of tough
immigration laws in many states.[66][67][68][69] According to the [Pew
Hispanic Center](/wiki/Pew_Hispanic_Center "Pew Hispanic Center") the net
immigration of Mexican born persons had stagnated in 2010, and tended toward
going into negative figures.[70]

More than 80 cities in the United States,[71] including [Washington
D.C.](/wiki/Washington_D.C. "Washington D.C."), [New York
City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"), [Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles
"Los Angeles"), [Chicago](/wiki/Chicago "Chicago"), [San
Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco"), [San Diego](/wiki/San_Diego
"San Diego"), [San Jose](/wiki/San_Jose,_California "San Jose, California"),
[Salt Lake City](/wiki/Salt_Lake_City "Salt Lake City"),
[Phoenix](/wiki/Phoenix,_Arizona "Phoenix, Arizona"), [Dallas](/wiki/Dallas
"Dallas"), [Fort Worth](/wiki/Fort_Worth,_Texas "Fort Worth, Texas"),
[Houston](/wiki/Houston "Houston"), [Detroit](/wiki/Detroit "Detroit"),
[Jersey City](/wiki/Jersey_City "Jersey City"),
[Minneapolis](/wiki/Minneapolis "Minneapolis"), [Denver](/wiki/Denver

The United States admitted more legal immigrants from 1991 to 2000, between
ten and eleven million, than in any previous decade. In the most recent
decade, the ten million legal immigrants that settled in the U.S. represent an
annual growth of only about 0.3% as the U.S. population grew from 249 million
to 281 million. By comparison, the highest previous decade was the 1900s, when
8.8 million people arrived, increasing the total U.S. population by one
percent every year. Specifically, "nearly 15% of Americans were foreign-born
in 1910, while in 1999, only about 10% were foreign-born."[80]

By 1970, immigrants accounted for 4.7 percent of the US population and rising
to 6.2 percent in 1980, with an estimated 12.5 percent in 2009.[81] As of
2010[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Immigration_to_the_United_States&action=edit),
25% of US residents under age 18 were first- or second-generation
immigrants.[82] Eight percent of all babies born in the U.S. in 2008 belonged
to illegal immigrant parents, according to a recent analysis of U.S. Census
Bureau data by the Pew Hispanic Center.[83]

Legal immigration to the U.S. increased from 250,000 in the 1930s, to 2.5
million in the 1950s, to 4.5 million in the 1970s, and to 7.3 million in the
1980s, before resting at about 10 million in the 1990s.[84] Since 2000, legal
immigrants to the United States number approximately 1,000,000 per year, of
whom about 600,000 are _Change of Status_ who already are in the U.S. Legal
immigrants to the United States now are at their highest level ever, at just
over 37,000,000 legal immigrants. Illegal immigration may be as high as
1,500,000 per year with a net of at least 700,000 illegal immigrants arriving
every year.[85][86] Immigration led to a 57.4% increase in foreign born
population from 1990 to 2000.[87]

While immigration has increased drastically over the last century, the foreign
born share of the population is, at 13.4, only somewhat below what it was at
its peak in 1910 at 14.7%. A number of factors may be attributed to the
decrease in the representation of foreign born residents in the United States.
Most significant has been the change in the composition of immigrants; prior
to 1890, 82% of immigrants came from North and Western Europe. From 1891 to
1920, that number dropped to 25%, with a rise in immigrants from East,
Central, and South Europe, summing up to 64%. Animosity towards these
different and foreign immigrants rose in the United States, resulting in much
legislation to limit immigration.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Contemporary immigrants settle predominantly in seven states,
[California](/wiki/California "California"), [New
York](/wiki/New_York_\(state\) "New York \(state\)"), [Florida](/wiki/Florida
"Florida"), [Texas](/wiki/Texas "Texas"), [Pennsylvania](/wiki/Pennsylvania
"Pennsylvania"), [New Jersey](/wiki/New_Jersey "New Jersey") and
[Illinois](/wiki/Illinois "Illinois"), comprising about 44% of the U.S.
population as a whole. The combined total immigrant population of these seven
states was 70% of the total foreign-born population in 2000. If current [birth
rate](/wiki/List_of_countries_and_territories_by_fertility_rate "List of
countries and territories by fertility rate") and immigration rates were to
remain unchanged for another 70 to 80 years, the U.S. population would double
to nearly 600 million.[88] In fact, this growth would constitute a slowing
trend in US population, which grew by 3.7 times between 1900 and 2000.[89]

In 1900, when the U.S. population was 76 million, there were an estimated
500,000 Hispanics.[90] The [Census Bureau](/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau
"United States Census Bureau") projects that by 2050, one-quarter of the
population will be of Hispanic descent.[91] This demographic shift is largely
fueled by immigration from Latin America.[92][93]

## Effects of immigration

### Demographics

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Naturalization_ceremony_at_Kennedy_Space_Center.jpg/220px-
Naturalization_ceremony_at_Kennedy_Space_Center.jpg)](/wiki/File:Naturalization_ceremony_at_Kennedy_Space_Center.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Naturalization_ceremony_at_Kennedy_Space_Center.jpg "Enlarge")

A U.S. [naturalization](/wiki/Naturalization "Naturalization") ceremony at the
[Kennedy Space Center](/wiki/Kennedy_Space_Center "Kennedy Space Center"),
2010.

The Census Bureau estimates the US population will grow from 317 million in
2014 to 417 million in 2060 with immigration, when nearly 20% will be foreign
born.[96] A 2015 report from the [Pew Research
Center](/wiki/Pew_Research_Center "Pew Research Center") projects that by
2065, non-Hispanic [whites](/wiki/White_American "White American") will
account for 46% of the population, down from the 2005 figure of 67%.[97] Non-
Hispanic whites made up 85% of the population in 1960.[98] It also foresees
the [Hispanic](/wiki/Hispanic_and_Latino_Americans "Hispanic and Latino
Americans") population rising from 17% in 2014 to 29% by 2060. The
[Asian](/wiki/Asian_American "Asian American") population is expected to
nearly double in 2060.[96] Overall, the Pew Report predicts the population of
the United States will rise from 296 million in 2005 to 441 million in 2065,
but only to 338 million with no immigration.[97]

In 35 of the country's [50 largest
cities](/wiki/List_of_the_largest_metropolitan_areas_in_the_Americas "List of
the largest metropolitan areas in the Americas"), non-Hispanic whites were at
the last census or are predicted to be in the minority.[99] In California,
non-Hispanic whites slipped from 80% of the state's population in 1970 to 42%
in 2001[100] and 39% in 2013.[101]

Immigrant segregation declined in the first half of the 20th century, but has
been rising over the past few decades. This has caused questioning of the
correctness of describing the United States as a [melting
pot](/wiki/Melting_pot "Melting pot"). One explanation is that groups with
lower socioeconomic status concentrate in more densely populated area that
have access to [public transit](/wiki/Public_transit "Public transit") while
groups with higher socioeconomic status move to [suburban](/wiki/Suburban
"Suburban") areas. Another is that some recent immigrant groups are more
culturally and linguistically different from earlier groups and prefer to live
together due to factors such as communication costs.[102] Another explanation
for increased segregation is [white flight](/wiki/White_flight "White
flight").[103]

### Economic

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/San_Jose_May_Day_01.jpg/220px-
San_Jose_May_Day_01.jpg)](/wiki/File:San_Jose_May_Day_01.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:San_Jose_May_Day_01.jpg "Enlarge")

Mexican immigrants march for more rights in Northern California's largest
city, [San Jose](/wiki/San_Jose,_California "San Jose, California") (2006).

A survey of leading economists shows a consensus behind the view that high-
skilled immigration makes the average American better off.[104] A survey of
the same economists also shows strong support behind the notion that low-
skilled immigration makes the average American better off.[105] According to
[David Card](/wiki/David_Card "David Card"), Christian Dustmann, and Ian
Preston, "most existing studies of the economic impacts of immigration suggest
these impacts are small, and on average benefit the native population".[106]
In a survey of the existing literature, Örn B Bodvarsson and Hendrik Van den
Berg write, "a comparison of the evidence from all the studies ... makes it
clear that, with very few exceptions, there is no strong statistical support
for the view held by many members of the public, namely that immigration has
an adverse effect on native-born workers in the destination country."[107]

#### Overall economic prosperity

Whereas the impact on the average native tends to be small and positive,
studies show more mixed results for low-skilled natives, but whether the
effects are positive or negative, they tend to be small either way.[108]

Immigrants may often do types of work that natives are largely unwilling to
do, contributing to greater economic prosperity for the economy as a whole:
for instance, Mexican migrant workers taking up manual farm work in the United
States has close to zero effect on native employment in that occupation, which
means that the effect of Mexican workers on U.S. employment outside farm work
was therefore most likely positive, since they raised overall economic
productivity.[109] Research indicates that immigrants are more likely to work
in risky jobs than U.S.-born workers, partly due to differences in average
characteristics, such as immigrants' lower English language ability and
educational attainment.[110] Further, some studies indicate that higher ethnic
concentration in metropolitan areas is positively related to the probability
of self-employment of immigrants.[111]

Research also suggests that diversity has a net positive effect on
productivity[112][113] and economic prosperity.[114][114][115][116][117] A
study by [Nathan Nunn](/wiki/Nathan_Nunn "Nathan Nunn"), Nancy Qian and Sandra
Sequeira found that the Age of Mass Migration (1850–1920) has had
substantially beneficial long-term effects on U.S. economic prosperity:
"locations with more historical immigration today have higher incomes, less
poverty, less unemployment, higher rates of urbanization, and greater
educational attainment. The long-run effects appear to arise from the
persistence of sizeable short-run benefits, including earlier and more
intensive industrialization, increased agricultural productivity, and more
innovation."[118] The authors also find that the immigration had short-term
benefits: "that there is no evidence that these long-run benefits come at
short-run costs. In fact, immigration immediately led to economic benefits
that took the form of higher incomes, higher productivity, more innovation,
and more industrialization."[119]

Research also finds that migration leads to greater trade in goods and
services.[120][121][122][123] Using 130 years of data on historical migrations
to the United States, one study finds "that a doubling of the number of
residents with ancestry from a given foreign country relative to the mean
increases by 4.2 percentage points the probability that at least one local
firm invests in that country, and increases by 31% the number of employees at
domestic recipients of FDI from that country. The size of these effects
increases with the ethnic diversity of the local population, the geographic
distance to the origin country, and the ethno-linguistic fractionalization of
the origin country."[124]

Some research suggests that immigration can offset some of the adverse effects
of automation on native labor outcomes in the United States.[125][126] By
increasing overall demand, immigrants could push natives out of low-skilled
manual labor into better paying occupations.[125][126] A 2018 study in the
_American Economic Review_ found that the [Bracero
program](/wiki/Bracero_program "Bracero program") (which allowed almost half a
million Mexican workers to do seasonal farm labor in the United States) did
not have any adverse impact on the labor market outcomes of American-born farm
workers.[127]

#### Fiscal effects

A 2011 literature review of the economic impacts of immigration found that the
net fiscal impact of migrants varies across studies but that the most credible
analyses typically find small and positive fiscal effects on average.[128]
According to the authors, "the net social impact of an immigrant over his or
her lifetime depends substantially and in predictable ways on the immigrant's
age at arrival, education, reason for migration, and similar".[128]

A 2016 report by the [National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and
Medicine](/wiki/National_Academies_of_Sciences,_Engineering,_and_Medicine
"National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine") concluded that
over a 75-year time horizon, “the fiscal impacts of immigrants are generally
positive at the federal level and generally negative at the state and local
level.”[129] The reason for the costs to state and local governments is that
the cost of educating the immigrants' children falls on state and local
governments.[130] According to a 2007 literature review by the [Congressional
Budget Office](/wiki/Congressional_Budget_Office "Congressional Budget
Office"), "Over the past two decades, most efforts to estimate the fiscal
impact of immigration in the United States have concluded that, in aggregate
and over the long term, tax revenues of all types generated by immigrants—both
legal and unauthorized—exceed the cost of the services they use."[131]

According to James Smith, a senior economist at Santa Monica-based [RAND
Corporation](/wiki/RAND_Corporation "RAND Corporation") and lead author of the
[United States National Research
Council](/wiki/United_States_National_Research_Council "United States National
Research Council")'s study _"[The New Americans: Economic, Demographic, and
Fiscal Effects of
Immigration](/wiki/The_New_Americans:_Economic,_Demographic,_and_Fiscal_Effects_of_Immigration
"The New Americans: Economic, Demographic, and Fiscal Effects of
Immigration")"_, immigrants contribute as much as $10 billion to the [U.S.
economy](/wiki/U.S._economy "U.S. economy") each year.[132] The NRC report
found that although immigrants, especially those from Latin America, caused a
net loss in terms of taxes paid versus social services received, immigration
can provide an overall gain to the domestic economy due to an increase in pay
for higher-skilled workers, lower prices for goods and services produced by
immigrant labor, and more efficiency and lower wages for some owners of
capital. The report also notes that although immigrant workers compete with
[domestic workers](/wiki/Domestic_worker "Domestic worker") for low-skilled
jobs, some immigrants specialize in activities that otherwise would not exist
in an area, and thus can be beneficial for all domestic residents.[133]

Immigration and foreign labor documentation fees increased over 80% in 2007,
with over 90% of funding for USCIS derived from immigration application fees,
creating many USCIS jobs involving immigration to US, such as immigration
interview officials, finger print processor, Department of Homeland Security,
etc.[134]

#### Inequality

Overall immigration has not had much effect on native wage
inequality[135][136] but low-skill immigration has been linked to greater
income inequality in the native population.[137]

#### Impact of undocumented immigrants

Main article: [Economic impact of illegal immigrants in the United
States](/wiki/Economic_impact_of_illegal_immigrants_in_the_United_States
"Economic impact of illegal immigrants in the United States")

Research on the economic effects of undocumented immigrants is scant but
existing peer-reviewed studies suggest that the effects are positive for the
native population[138][139] and public coffers.[131] A 2015 study shows that
"increasing deportation rates and tightening border control weakens low-
skilled labor markets, increasing unemployment of native low-skilled workers.
Legalization, instead, decreases the unemployment rate of low-skilled natives
and increases income per native."[140] Studies show that legalization of
undocumented immigrants would boost the U.S. economy; a 2013 study found that
granting legal status to undocumented immigrants would raise their incomes by
a quarter (increasing U.S. GDP by approximately $1.4 trillion over a ten-year
period),[141] and 2016 study found that "legalization would increase the
economic contribution of the unauthorized population by about 20%, to 3.6% of
private-sector GDP."[142]

A 2007 literature by the [Congressional Budget
Office](/wiki/Congressional_Budget_Office "Congressional Budget Office") found
that estimating the fiscal effects of undocumented immigrants has proven
difficult: "currently available estimates have significant limitations;
therefore, using them to determine an aggregate effect across all states would
be difficult and prone to considerable error". The impact of undocumented
immigrants differs on federal levels than state and local levels,[131] with
research suggesting modest fiscal costs at the state and local levels but with
substantial fiscal gains at the federal level.[143]

In 2009, a study by the [Cato Institute](/wiki/Cato_Institute "Cato
Institute"), a [free market](/wiki/Free_market "Free market") [think
tank](/wiki/Think_tank "Think tank"), found that legalization of low-skilled
illegal resident workers in the US would result in a net increase in US GDP of
$180 billion over ten years.[144] The Cato Institute study did not examine the
impact on per capita income for most Americans. Jason Riley notes that because
of progressive income taxation, in which the top 1% of earners pay 37% of
federal income taxes (even though they actually pay a lower tax percentage
based on their income), 60% of Americans collect more in government services
than they pay in, which also reflects on immigrants.[145] In any event, the
typical immigrant and his children will pay a net $80,000 more in their
lifetime than they collect in government services according to the NAS.[146]
Legal immigration policy is set to maximize net taxation. Illegal immigrants
even after an amnesty tend to be recipients of more services than they pay in
taxes. In 2010, an [econometrics](/wiki/Econometrics "Econometrics") study by
a [Rutgers](/wiki/Rutgers_University "Rutgers University")
[economist](/wiki/Economist "Economist") found that immigration helped
increase bilateral trade when the incoming people were connected via networks
to their country of origin, particularly boosting trade of [final
goods](/wiki/Final_goods "Final goods") as opposed to [intermediate
goods](/wiki/Intermediate_goods "Intermediate goods"), but that the trade
benefit weakened when the immigrants became assimilated into American
culture.[147]

According to NPR in 2005, about 3% of illegal immigrants were working in
[agriculture](/wiki/Agriculture_in_the_United_States "Agriculture in the
United States").[148] The [H-2A visa](/wiki/H-2A_visa "H-2A visa") allows U.S.
employers to bring foreign nationals to the United States to fill
[temporary](/wiki/Guest_worker_program "Guest worker program") agricultural
jobs.[149] The passing of tough immigration laws in several states from around
2009 provides a number of practical case studies. The state of Georgia passed
immigration law [HB 87](/wiki/HB_87 "HB 87") in 2011;[150] this led, according
to the coalition of top Kansas businesses, to 50% of its agricultural produce
being left to rot in the fields, at a cost to the state of more than $400
million. Overall losses caused by the act were $1 billion; it was estimated
that the figure would become over $20 billion if all the estimated 325,000
unauthorized workers left Georgia. The cost to Alabama of its crackdown in
June 2011 has been estimated at almost $11 billion, with up to 80,000
unauthorized immigrant workers leaving the state.[151]

#### Impact of refugees

Studies of refugees' impact on native welfare are scant but the existing
literature shows a positive fiscal impact and mixed results (negative,
positive and no significant effects) on native welfare.[152][153][154][155] A
2017 paper by Evans and Fitzgerald found that refugees to the United States
pay "$21,000 more in taxes than they receive in benefits over their first 20
years in the U.S."[154] An internal study by the Department of Health and
Human Services under the Trump administration, which was suppressed and not
shown to the public, found that refugees to the United States brought in $63
billion more in government revenues than they cost the government.[155]
According to labor economist Giovanni Peri, the existing literature suggests
that there are no economic reasons why the American labor market could not
easily absorb 100,000 Syrian refugees in a year.[156] Refugees integrate more
slowly into host countries' labor markets than labor migrants, in part due to
the loss and depreciation of human capital and credentials during the asylum
procedure.[157]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Chinatown_manhattan_2009.JPG/220px-
Chinatown_manhattan_2009.JPG)](/wiki/File:Chinatown_manhattan_2009.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Chinatown_manhattan_2009.JPG "Enlarge")

Garment factories in [Manhattan's Chinatown](/wiki/Chinatown,_Manhattan
"Chinatown, Manhattan")

#### Innovation and entrepreneurship

According to one survey of the existing economic literature, "much of the
existing research points towards positive net contributions by immigrant
entrepreneurs."[158] Areas where immigrant are more prevalent in the United
States have substantially more innovation (as measured by patenting and
citations).[159] Immigrants to the United States create businesses at higher
rates than natives.[160] According to a 2018 paper, "first-generation
immigrants create about 25% of new firms in the United States, but this share
exceeds 40% in some states."[161] Another 2018 paper links H-1B visa holders
to innovation.[162]

Immigrants have been linked to greater invention and innovation in the
US.[163] According to one report, "immigrants have started more than half (44
of 87) of America's startup companies valued at $1 billion or more and are key
members of management or product development teams in over 70 percent (62 of
87) of these companies."[164] Foreign doctoral students are a major source of
innovation in the American economy.[165] In the United States, immigrant
workers hold a disproportionate share of jobs in science, technology,
engineering, and math (STEM): "In 2013, foreign-born workers accounted for
19.2 percent of STEM workers with a bachelor's degree, 40.7 percent of those
with a master's degree, and more than half—54.5 percent—of those with a
Ph.D."[166]

The Kauffman Foundation's index of entrepreneurial activity is nearly 40%
higher for immigrants than for natives.[167] Immigrants were involved in the
founding of many prominent American high-tech companies, such as Google,
Yahoo, YouTube, Sun Microsystems, and eBay.[168]

[](/wiki/File:Andrew_Carnegie_by_Francis_Luis_Mora.jpg "Enlarge")

Scottish immigrant [Andrew Carnegie](/wiki/Andrew_Carnegie "Andrew Carnegie")
led the enormous expansion of the American [steel
industry](/wiki/Steel_industry "Steel industry") in the late 19th century.
